positive.review: I started Wuthering Waves about a month after its Steam launch, and honestly, I haven't missed a single day since. I’m writing this after hitting 100% completion on absolutely everything: the map, every quest, all holograms, and even the end-game modes. And after all that, this game is a solid 10/10 for me. I’ve spent countless hours on Destiny 2 and Dota over the years, and Wuthering Waves has still managed to be the game I've spent most time playing this year.

A mixed experience of a gacha game for me, but overall I would recommend. The game's best in the 'honeymoon' period when you haven't run out of content to do yet or characters to level. 

Pros:
1. Visually stunning. Your thermals might take a hike, but the game looks breathtaking at higher settings, especially in 4k. Cut-scene direction and camerawork is great and dynamic, especially in the later quests. 
2. Voice acting in the later patches is stellar: despite there being quite the uproar over subpar voice acting when the game released, the recent patches have not only fixed the issue, but gone above and beyond. I play in EN audio, and especially the VAs of Iuno and Carlotta have done a stellar job of it.
3. Combat is fun and diverse enough. Didn't axe mechanics like perfect dodges and perfect counters, as some gachas do when they're also on mobile. Character animations are often visually great and creative.
4. Some of the story is good: although the whole picture is kind of mixed. The story is at its worst in those first stretches of quests, but gets exponentially better as time goes on.
5. Amazing music: especially the scores in Rinascita.
6. Relatively challenging endgame: this will vary depending on skill level, character investment and how much you might have whaled, but generally there's a good amount of challenging content to work towards.
7. Somewhat generous gacha. Not ideal by any means, but has some nice things that competitors don't, like buying a copy of a limited character you've already got (albeit for quite a bit of currency) and not having a 50/50 or 33/67 on the weapon banner (*cough cough* Genshin).
8. Fun characters. Some are same-y, but most have something unique about them or their stories that makes them at the very least briefly interesting.

Cons:
1. It's a gacha game. It updates periodically, so there will be powercreep, and the main goal will always be to get plays to swipe for characters.
2. Teams locked behind spending. A lot of characters lately come with 'best partners' - limited, of course - that make a massive difference to damage output. Doesn't mean the characters are unplayable without their partner, but they're a lot complete (Zani-Phoebe, Cartwheel-Ciaconna, Augusta-Iuno, Phrolova-Cantarella-Qiuyuan, etc.)
3. Very few four-stars. Not a problem unique to this game, but a problem nonetheless. Most four-stars are not very good (with some exceptions, of course) and there are not very many of them. 
4. Gooner elements: which is not a secret to anybody. The women in this game are sexualized to sometimes a comical degree, such a jiggle physics jiggling through a solid piece of METAL chest-plate (lookin' at you, Augusta), and overall looking incredibly uncanny, like they're made of water and not flesh. Standard levels of stupidity in character design, as well (most of the women are half-naked, even when it doesn't make any sense). Most will also simp for the MC or have narratively unearned romantic moments, which gets annoying somewhere after the third time.
5. For people who enjoy having playable men, this might not be the best game. They are very few and far between, and often end up relegated to supporting roles (or, for example like in Qiuyuan's case, their DPS playstyle is locked behind several copies).
6. Nothing to do once you've caught up to the story. A usual problem for live-service gacha games. Events are often boring and one-note, and once you've logged in, done dailies and farmed mats, there's not very much left to do. This is perfectly fine if you play casually and have longer bursts of playtime whenever a new update comes out, but if you're looking for something to play regularly, you might be disappointed in how little there is to do after a certain point.

10/10 – I Don’t Even Know Why I’m This Hooked

I’ve got over 30 hours in Wuthering Waves so far, and I still don’t really understand what kind of magic this game has on me. All I want to do is log in, grind, explore, and fight more bosses.

The world is massive and surprisingly alive — the music, the combat flow, the character animations — everything just clicks. The combat feels insanely good once you start chaining dodges, parries, and echoes together. It’s like every fight has its own rhythm.

I told myself I’d just do a few daily quests... next thing I know, it’s 3AM and I’m farming echoes or trying out new team comps for the tenth time.

It’s not perfect — the early game pacing and some voice lines can be a bit rough — but it’s improving fast, and honestly, I don’t even care. The game just feels good to play.

If you love open worlds, stylish combat, and games that pull you in without you realizing how much time has passed — Wuthering Waves will eat your free time and make you thank it for doing so.

The world is beautiful in every region, with stunning landscapes and stylish cities that make exploring a joy. The music fits perfectly too, adding atmosphere whether you’re gliding through a valley or fighting a boss.

Characters? Gorgeous. Every new banner feels like the devs want us to keep “gathering wives,” and honestly… we’re all happily doing it.


[b]Cons[/b]

	•	Occasional performance issues on weaker devices.

Overall: If you want a gacha game with top-tier combat, great visuals, amazing vibes, and characters you’ll definitely fall in love with, Wuthering Waves is absolutely worth playing.

After hearing some of my friends rave for days on end about how good this game is, I eventually [strike]was forced[/strike] decided to give it a try. The beginning of the game is similar to what I expected from a Chinese gacha game, with the story taking place in a post-apocalyptic civilization with destroyed modern cities full of monsters. These monsters, named Tacet Discords, are the main enemies you usually find throughout the game, sporting some of the coolest and most unique designs in the game, ranging from beastly to biomechanical abominations.

Similar to what happens with FFXIV, the initial Jinzhou storyline has some pacing issues, probably due to limited resources from the developers during the release of the game. However, once you're done with the Jinzhou zone, the game really opens up and the story picks up the pace. I was pleasantly surprised by how many different influences from western cultures converge in this game, including French, Italian, Greek or Roman aesthetics in some of the later zones. The characters' motivations and stakes grow as the storyline progresses, with multiple plot twists and really complex concepts and problems these characters need to understand and solve in order to move forward. These problems are never waved away for the sake of convenience, and at times it really feels like everything can go to shit at any minute during the MSQ if the protagonist doesn't lock in.

The soundtrack includes some real bangers, with a mix of trance, techno, rock or pop music depending on the context of the quests and zones in the game. I can't explain with words how good the background and combat songs for the [spoiler]Septimont[/spoiler] zone are, it is something you need to experience yourself.

Regarding the playable characters that appear throughout the game, I was pleasantly surprised to discover that, even though some of them are somewhat sexualized, they are ACTUAL CHARACTERS, with personal development and personalities, instead of being reduced to plain eye candy similar to what happens in other gacha games. Every frame in each of these characters' animations is clearly crafted with love. The models are really high quality, and the skill design and artstyle are legitimately outstanding, especially for later units such as Cartethyia, Quiyuan or Chisa.

Since this is a gacha, yes, you need to pull from banners for some 5-star units (resonators) and weapons, with some of them being time-limited, and requiring players to wait for the banner to come back if they miss it or don't get the unit before it goes away. There is a hard-pity system in place which ensures that you are guaranteed to get a 5-star resonator within 80 pulls. However, there's a 50% chance you get the banner-specific resonator, making it painfully annoying if you "miss" this 50/50 and need to keep pulling... However, the game is pretty generous with Astrite, the premium currency which can be obtained throughout the MSQ, side quests or open-world exploration chests and bosses, allowing for multiple pulls before you even need to spend any money if you have any semblance of patience.

This game is an absolute banger, really addictive, with a really solid story and fluid gameplay. The aesthetics are completely outstanding, with intense orchestral music, and cinematic, exciting and at times even challenging bosses. I am honestly surprised this game is only a year old with the huge amount of high quality content it already has. Additional props to the English translation team, which managed to adapt the game to western audiences, sneaking in later zones some easter eggs and somewhat obscure references to western media in quests and dialogues, it certainly got a chuckle out of me. Really recommend this game if you are willing to completely destroy your sleep schedule for the better part of two weeks or so.

Despite Wuthering Waves being a gacha game, this never holds it back. The gameplay, characters, world, exploration, and music are of extremely high quality, and with every update, it delivers richer and more dynamic features that further immerse you in this innovative world. 

Personally, I play this game for the story and characters. I have absolutely fallen in love with the narrative Kuro is trying to convey. It is undoubtedly one of the most visually stunning, thematically rich, and emotionally resonant stories I’ve encountered in a video game. It offers everything that matters to me in a story and so much more.

This game has an overwhelming number of qualities that I couldn't do justice to in just a brief review. Rover feels authentic, natural, progressive, flawed, and grounded. While some might say this story is about "gathering" wives, that couldn't be further from the truth. Rover's thematic journey revolves around fate versus free will. Can they unite humanity and overcome the fated end that the Lament poses? There are many deep and intricate layers to their character, how they tie in with the world itself, the people they save, and the overarching narrative. 

On top of Rover, the antagonists in this story are some of the most metafictional, creative, well-written, and engaging characters I’ve ever seen. They consistently deliver in terms of presentation, which only makes you more invested. They challenge Rover in a way that makes you question the choices they've made throughout their journey, as well as the core values of the world and humanity itself. I won't spoil who they are or what they do. I simply urge you to find out for yourself.

The side characters are also fantastic. Especially from Rinascita (2.0) onwards, they are all brimming with life. The 1.0 story and its characters are still great, but the storytelling is weaker, which has led to less investment from people, and I completely understand that. However, every side character in 2.0 onwards has amazing dynamics with Rover. They genuinely feel like their own individuals, with emotionally cathartic backstories, realistic ideals, and world views. While some of the female characters have romance, it never detracts from their individuality. They are not reduced to mere accessories - they have their own ambitions, motivations, and ideals separate from Rover. Kuro makes an active effort to demonstrate this, and they have accomplished it fantastically.

Gameplay-wise, it only complements the story being told. It becomes deeper with each update, the character kits become more complex, and they continuously add unique and engaging mechanics that breathe EVEN more life into the system, enhancing its incredible addictiveness. The exploration throughout the game is amazing and serves to connect the world while building upon it. The only gripe I have so far is in the later regions, where it is admittedly quite hand-holdy. Other than that, the game is stunning, rich, and keeps you unlocking quests, hidden secrets, and amazing lore that's scattered across this vast world. 

In terms of the Gacha system in this game, it is relatively fair. I've managed to pull every character I've wanted, and they are quite generous with the amount of pulls you receive as a F2P player. The best thing about the Gacha system is that the weapon banners are guaranteed. This means that when you reach 80 pulls (pity), you are guaranteed to receive the weapon of your choice. Unfortunately, characters still have a pity system, but it's a lot less taxing when you don't have to worry about losing your 50/50 on BOTH the character and weapon banners. Whilst there is still a bit of grinding, I wouldn't say it's tedious if you're a casual player. Especially since the in-game rewards system for levelling is generous, so you earn lot of pulls from simply progressing the main story. 

All in all, this is absolutely a F2P game worth getting invested in. Kuro games consistently makes the game better, listens to player feedback, innovates, improves the world, gameplay, and narrative. If you love anime or manga series like Bleach, Re:Zero, Steins;Gate, Cyberpunk (Edgerunners/2077), or even if you simply enjoy romance stories, I think you'll definitely find some value in this game.

TL:DR - Amazing and highly praised story elements that deeply impact its players. Outstanding and unbelievable gacha win rates (alleged 65/35 rather than 50/50, and weapon banner is guaranteed, no 50/50 luck). Polished and wonderful combat mechanics, with fresh and interesting gameplay changes. Parrying and counter attacks feel satisfying. Graphics are astonishing, Realism and interactability is highly focused and perfectly executed. Graphic-Framerate issues due to intense graphics and lighting effects (UE game, doing UE things). 

Final Verdict: Highly recommended game, for the story and graphics alone, without even going into the f2p-friendly gacha system.


**FULL REVIEW** 

As a lore-dedicated and immersed player, Wuthering Waves has one of the best, if not the best stories I have ever experienced in a gacha game. Each story feels more exciting and more improved than the last. Most of the stories, especially the recent ones are so well animated, you may even consider them as anime episodes. Though be prepared to given an increasing dose of depression as you progress through the main story.

For you gamblers and gacha enjoyers, it has been mathematically proven that your account's first 50/50 has a higher winning chance than any other game, and winning the 50/50 gamble it self is much easier than it actually seems, with an average (at least according to my experience, observations, and calculations) of 65/35 gamble rather than the supposed 50/50. Additionally to this, the weapon banner has no 50% of winning once you obtain a 5* star. You are guaranteed a win no matter what.

As someone who has played since WuWa came out (beginning on the official launcher and only porting over to Steam recently) I have won 7 out of the 9 featured banner 5* star characters, that is about ~77% winning chance on a 50/50 roll in a gacha, which is crazy good, especially for someone who grew up playing FGO, and played every MiHoYo game since their launch (except HI3).  

The combat mechanics are excellent. As someone who deeply praised souls-like games, PGR, Ghost of Tsushima and Yotei, as well as realism in games, I am in love with the way Kuro Games has dealt and polished the combat in this game. Perfectly timed and wonderfully polished counters, timed attacks, QTEs, parries, and much more. Weapons and attacks have near perfect hitboxes and actually seem realistic and makes sense, no glitches, asset teleportation, hitbox errors, and such. Combat mechanics feel fresh and rewarding. For average gamers, you would think of constant attacks towards your enemy, but no, here you actually have to learn parrying, counterattacking, QTEs, proper team setups and rotations, the likes. 

Lastly, for those seeking graphic feedback. The graphics are outstanding and highly polished. Most of the environments and objects are perfected and beautified just the right amount. Interactable environments, like breakable objects (boxes, crates, vases, stones, etc.), moving foliage (i.e. grass/flowers move as you go through them), attacks, especially those that include or control wind/air move light objects like leaves around or makes them go up in the air. Furthermore, the lighting is magnificent. Shadows are highly effective and accurate, even on the lowest graphic settings. Subsurface scattering (basically, imagine how light passes through your fingers) looks quite realistic. Ambient lighting works so well with the environment it is placed in. 
Now, I am aware that the game does run poorly on a lot of devices, especially on mobile devices. Yes this is a major issue, as the game would be better if it was more accessible to way more players (I play on a decent gaming laptop which runs the game on moderate graphics pretty well, but I am aware of how badly it runs on worse devices as I also play it on my *potato* off a phone, barely getting 20 frames on the lowest graphic settings). Unfortunately, I do not have the power to fix these issues, and I can't really recommend any other tip or advice to players experiencing such but:

*For PC players: (not in any order)
1.) Make sure you run the game on DirectX11 (this setting is found on the official launcher under the 'launch game' button, and on steam during first launch)
2.) Just lower your graphic settings, don't burden your pc/laptop too much, its better to play on worse graphics with more frames than realistic graphics on a slideshow.
3.) Try to ensure that you do not have too many background applications or programs, especially those that are gpu heavy (editing software, model generators, etc.)
4.) Ensure that Wuthering Waves is set to use your dedicated (or best gpu) in your pc's gaming setting (just look up how to do this, its quite simple)
5.) Double check that you are on your best performance setting on your pc/laptop, and if you are using a pc, please ensure that your monitor is connected to your dedicated gpu (if available) and not the cpu's gpu (igpu).

*For Mobile players: (not in any order)
1.) Lower your graphic settings, especially for phones that aren't built for graphic-intense games. Remember this is a UE game, it is known to be unstable and resource inefficient. 
2.) Double check if you have a setting/setup on your phone that enables *Game Mode* or *Ultra Game Mode* or maybe even *Esports Mode*. If it does, ensure that Wuthering Waves is tagged as a game under this list. These setups allow you to dedicate your phone's resources to the game so that it *hopefully* runs smoother.

*For Console players:
1.) Not really sure what I can give to help you, as consoles don't really allow for a lot of graphic setting changes, as consoles basically all have the same specs..

Much of the main story is so bad that it reads like some absolute bottom tier fanfiction, with a completely uninteresting mary sue main character, constant deus ex machinas and "... and then this other thing happened" storytelling, and antagonists that are basically just saturday morning cartoon villains. Something you might hear said about the writing in this game is that it gets better as you progress, but it actually just gets worse. The game starts out boring, sure, but it ends up god awful. You should NOT play this game for the story. If you are considering it, play literally anything else instead. I promise that whatever you choose, it will be a better choice.

However, for me who didn't start playing for the story anyway, the BIGGEST problem with this game is how it uses its combat and characters. This is rather big topic, because the combat system itself is actually pretty good, but the problem is that it's never used for anything interesting or worthwhile, and neither are the characters. Whatever effort or money you put into getting a character and levelling them is wasted, as there is almost nothing to do with them outside of running around in the overworld and just looking at them.

The main attraction for me in this game was the combat, and the moment you get far enough to understand it, where you learn attack rotations, etc, you learn how to blow up regular enemies in seconds. The only challenge in the game will be a handful of timed challenges and bosses, and that is literally all you get. "End game" as it were, consists of one mode that pretends to be a roguelite-thing, that resets weekly and is so easy that you can probably do it blindfolded in less than 10 minutes; two modes that reset monthly that are mainly DPS checks (with one also being just a hard check for whether you have a character with a skill that sucks in groups of enemies); and a set of hologram bosses that are powered up versions of story bosses.

Once you get to these, you quickly find that the modes that reset are incredibly monotonous and boring. You either have a good enough team for them, or you don't. Either way, they take 15-30 minutes each after each reset, and then you are done with all combat content for that month. The hologram bosses are genuinely challenging and also require extremely good teams to do their strongest versions, so they are a more interesting, but they are one-and-dones, so it's not really something that keeps you entertained, and they are definitely not by themselves enough to be worth spending hundreds of hours (and probably money) to get to.

So outside of those, what is there to do in this game? Nothing that uses the combat system for anything. You can farm materials for levelling up characters, but only a few times a day because of the extremely limiting stamina system, and the farming is the most boring thing. You either fight a boss or a group of enemies, but they are super weak, so you can just button mash and be done in 10 seconds and get your reward. It's mindless and doesn't require anything from the combat system at all. So if you have spent time and money building a good team, those are the things you can do with it. There is nothing else.

You MIGHT think that you would find use for your team for example in story quests or in the "events" that are part of each patch, but that would be wrong. In story quests, you are always GIVEN a team, usually of characters you don't know how to play. Usually the main character plus the new character. And since you don't know how to play with them, the combat content in any and all quests are absolutely trivial, because the devs do not want you to get stuck. All the big quests are either just about mashing through boring combat, or they do not have combat at all.

And as for the events, I started playing this game earlier this year, and I think there has been a SINGLE event where I had to use any of the teams I built. Events are basically always non-combat events, or they are fake "combat" events, like some bad Vampire Survivors-clone that has nothing to do with the actual combat.

So once you get to the point where you feel that you have finished building a good team (which I thought was the goal), there is nothing to use it on. You log in, spend 3 minutes doing boring dailies that you could have done with a solo free character, and then log out. Once or twice a month you can log in and spend 15 minutes on whatever reset, and then log out.

The ONLY goal after that, is to save up for a new character, build a new team, and then again run out of things to do. Which is maybe by design. Hmm, maybe I am complaining about it being a gacha game after all.

Anyway, in conclusion, I can not recommend this game. Don't make the same mistake I made and think this is going to get good, because it's not. If you want a good story, play literally anything else. If you want action and combat, ALSO play literally anything else, because you don't get any combat here anyway.

tl;dr WuWa's only as fun as the sponge fest grind that holds it back. And for pure F2P players like me, that grind is no longer sustainable.

I've been playing WuWa since launch (1.0), long before its steam debut (2.0 I think, don't remember), safe to say I've poured in a fair bit of time into the game and I've had the chance to play everything there is. My actual playtime exceeds 200+ hours, Steam shows less since I linked my account late. I'm not going to highlight much on the story, since it's pretty much an echo (pun intended) of what everyone else would tell you; underwhelming at the start, leaves you gripping your seat and screaming "Absolute Cinema" in the later arcs, at least until the end of Carte's Ragunna arc for me (2.5). 

What I am going to talk about is how grindy the game has become in recent times. Let me make one thing clear; I'm a really stubborn F2P player. I never spend on any game that I play whatsoever, mainly because I just don't have the money to spare, ever. I don't ever touch on any of the high-level combat game modes like Tower of Adversity or any of the other combat related events. Don't get me wrong, combat in WuWa. 

But the thing that irks me is how UNGODLY levels of spongy the enemies can get. Not a skill issue on my part (I’ve cleared every story boss and hard-mode content with just Spectro-Rover C6/ Sanhua C6/ Shorekeeper C3). Now you might be inclined to tell me to just build a better team instead of sticking to one, that there's a lot of variety. To which I will reply "That's cool and all but where do I find two months of grinding for a team that’ll only marginally ease temporary event content?". Like you might have the willpower to grind all 4 Major locations in WuWa to 100% completion, but I just don't have that kind of energy. The collection grind is monotonous, echo farming that can clearly be automated is manual every SINGLE time and to make matters worse, any and all casual events are padded all to hell. At most, 10 minutes of fun into 3 hours of filler (Riccholi fishing event or Solaris Film Festival). At this point, WuWa feels less like a gacha and more like a modern Ubisoft title. If I wanted to grind that bad, I would've just opted to play Warframe.

That brings me to the second point, let's say I did grind a long while and got all the resources together. What about the emotional burnout it takes on me when I literally fail on two different banners for a new team that I've wanted to build? What do I do when I grind all of Ragunna for Zani but Instead of Zani I get a Verina dupe that turns into extra corals because I already have Verina at C6? Can't get Pheobe anymore either because not enough time to. No issue, just grind for Ciaccona and Carte. I get Ciaccona and then I go to grind for Carte, long time to her banner btw so I'm stacked on pulls for her. Whoops, too bad you get an Encore dupe. 

So now I got 48+ hours of playtime for absolutely nothing and not even a decent team out of it. I really don't think any whalers or grinders will understand how debilitating it is to feel that loss because they'll just pull their wallets out when in doubt or grind everything till hell freezes over. Me? I'll just stop playing I guess. Like I get it's a 50/50, and I genuinely understand that's the odds I'm playing at. But it really feels debilitating when the game you've spent so much time enjoying gives you the real shocker that it's just an advertisement for new characters in the story that'll probably have 0 role in the story post event. Their entire role becomes disillusioned like this, like the story wants me to care for them deeply as characters only to have them disappear post-banner.

The pacing is all over the place, not to mention how me not being able to get Carte actively hindered me from enjoying the story because that was on my mind the entire time, and I just wanted to get through it as quickly as possible so I could catch up content wise. I will say the ending to the Septimont arc (2.6) was really well executed. Even with all my banner losses looming over me, I genuinely enjoyed the final arc and all the fan service they put in.

Bottom line, I love WuWa. But in recent times, it's gotten really hard to stick with it because now it's focusing more on padding content out for player retention and making things generally harder so that players whale more. F2P friendly doesn't mean it's satisfying to play as a F2P, it means you can clear the entire game from start to finish with any of the free characters available to you, but to get to a point where they are all decently powered enough to ice you through everything is a long stretch. 

[b] If you're someone who doesn't see grinding as a problem, this game is for you. [/b] If you're someone like me who's not only short on time to play games but also plays them for fun, it's not for you.

Because of this, my CPU temperature skyrockets, the fans go into overdrive, and the entire system becomes stressed — all during what should be a simple loading sequence. It’s baffling that such a critical and hardware-intensive task is executed in this manner.This isn’t just an inconvenience; it makes the game practically unplayable for me. I genuinely wanted to dive into the world of Wuthering Waves, but instead I’m left monitoring hardware temperatures and worrying about long-term damage. No player should have to choose between enjoying a game and protecting their PC.
As it currently stands, I am deeply dissatisfied with the technical state of Wuthering Waves. Until the developers address these optimization issues — especially the unnecessary CPU-heavy compilation step — I cannot recommend the game. It’s a promising title held back by avoidable and potentially harmful design decisions
